Issue.Title: Deleted files don't appear in Recycle Bin
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**: 16.4.3
**Summary**: Files deleted from the solution explorer in Visual Studio do not appear in Recycle Bin. I've this [this bug](https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/issues/5710) from December 2019. It seems fixed (I tested it) for folders but this issue still exists for files.
**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. Create a .NET Core 3.1 project and open it with Visual Studio
2. Delete a class like (eg: `Program.cs`)
3. Open your Recycle Bin and notice your file isn't here
**Expected Behavior**: The deleted file is in the Recycle Bin
**Actual Behavior**: The deleted file isn't in the Recycle Bin
**User Impact**: Any decision to delete a file is not reversible. No second thought allowed

Issue.Title: Solution Explorer search in VisualFSharp.sln consistently crashes VS
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**:
Latest dogfood for me (29617.129.master)
**Summary**:
Consistent VS crash
**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. Clone https://github.com/dotnet/fsharp
2. Run `build.cmd` (may take a while to complete)
3. Open VisualFSharp.sln
4. Click Solution Explorer search
5. Search for "language" and hit Enter.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6309070/71112891-5e036500-2181-11ea-8e28-0a1cec9a3393.png)
**Expected Behavior**:
Filters solution explorer.
**Actual Behavior**:
Filters, but will either hang VS for a while and then crash, or will crash immediately.
**User Impact**:
Cannot use solution explorer to search in my codebase.

**Repro steps:** git clone https://github.com/AArnott/MessagePack-CSharp.git cd MessagePack-CSharp notepad sandbox\PerfNetFramework\PerfNetFramework.csproj Add the following line to the first PropertyGroup and save the file.

Use Visual Studio 2019 to open MessagePack.sln
Hangs about halfway through synchronous solution open. Dump file: https://microsoft-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/p/andarno/EfHFHj9yCqpPizs4OCIDJL0B6IEAG3JBAyT4pQTSp3SjNg?e=cvYVXn Stacks and !dumpasync: see text file attached to above linked Azure DevOps issue

Issue.Title: UI for "PackageVersion" in C# Project Properties does not update the PackageVersion tag in the .csproj file
Issue.Description:
Originally uncovered in report of a Nuget Issue: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7542 Considered to be a VS UI bug, rather than a Nuget Pack bug.
**Visual Studio Version**: I have personally reproduced it on: 2017 Professional. 2017 Community. 2019 Professional.
**Summary**: Setting the "PackageVersion" in the VS UI, modifies the `<Version>` tag, but not the `<PackageVersion>` tag, in the `.csproj` file.
Packing appears to use either tag, but take PackageVersion for preference. Thus the UI doesn't reliably update the output package version. **Steps to Reproduce**:
1. Create a new .NET Core ClassLibrary Project 2. Open the .csproj file and observe <PackageVersion> and <Version> are absent 3. In VS. Project > Properties > Package. 4. Enable "Package on Build" 5. Build, and observer a 1.0.0 package created. 6. In VS UI edit PackageVersion to 2.0.0. Save and Rebuild. 7. Observe that the `.csproj` file now has `<Version>2.0.0</Version>` and the `.nupkg` is 2.0.0 8. Edit the `.csproj` file to add `<PackageVersion>3.0.0</PackageVersion>`. Save and Rebuild. 9. Observe that UI still say 2, but the pkg is now 3. 10. Edit the UI to set "PackageVersion" to 4.0.0 . Save and Rebuild. 11. Observe that the `.csproj` file now has `<Version>4.0.0</Version>` but still has `<PackageVersion>3.0.0</PackageVersion>`, and the `.nupkg` is still 3.0.0
**Expected Behavior**: UI should update the <PackageVersion> tag. (Either as well as, or instead of, the <Version> tag.
**Actual Behavior**: UI only updates <Version> tag.
**User Impact**: Confusing UI that can end up mis-representing the Version that will be built.

Issue.Title: Copy paste .cs file from one Visual Studio instance to another
Issue.Description:
_This issue has a corresponding [ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/803508/copy-paste-cs-file-from-one-visual-studio-instance.html). Please vote and comment there to make sure your voice is heard._
--- I have opened two solutions, each in a separate Visual Studio window instance. I would like to copy a .cs file from Solution Explorer of the first VS instance to Solution Explorer of the second VS instance.
Now when I paste the .cs file into a folder in Solution Explorer of the second VS instance, a small dialog appears with the message "The source files for this operation cannot be found in this solution".
--- ### Original Comments

Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion. We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further. We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team.

Issue.Title: Project dropdown in code editor can't switch between .NET and .NET Core projects
Issue.Description:
_This issue has a corresponding [ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/584985/project-dropdown-in-code-editor-cant-switch-betwee.html). Please vote and comment there to make sure your voice is heard._ --- I have numerous solutions that contain .NET Framework and .NET Core projects, with common code in a Shared Project. In _theory_ it should be possible to use the project dropdown in the upper-left of the code window to switch views of my code files between different projects. This works in VS if no .NET Core projects are involved, but if there are both .NET Framework and .NET Core projects then any change to the combobox value is reset to the old value. 1. Open a solution such as https://github.com/marimerllc/csla `source/csla.test.sn` 1. Open a code file from the `Csla.Shared` project 1. Notice that the project dropdown shows 3 .NET Framework projects and 1 .NET Core project 1. Try to switch to a different project from whatever random one (?) VS chose when opening the file 1. Click back in the code window - notice that the dropdown changes back to its previous value The workaround I've found is to unload all projects that I don't want to see, leaving VS with no option but to show the view I want. This is tedious however, as then I need to reload all those projects to build/test, etc. --- ### Original Comments #### Visual Studio Feedback System on 5/28/2019, 05:56 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Milan Simic on 7/28/2019, 10:06 PM:

Still exists in v16.2.0

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Issue.Title: Cannot switch from "Icon and Manifest" to "Resource File"
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**:
VisualStudio.16.IntPreview/16.3.0-pre.2.0+29128.8.master
**Summary**:
It's difficult to change from "Icon and Manifest" to "Resource File" in .NET Core project because it switches back to "Icon and Manifest" before I can click browse after selecting "Resource File"
Repro is not 100%, and eventually it will settle down and stay on Resource File. But usually I can hit this following the steps below, as can @wli3
**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. File -> New Project -> .NET Core Console App
2. Solution Explorer -> Right click project -> properties
3. Application tab, under resources -> select "Resource file"
![cantpickresourcefile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/75470/62087316-36355400-b216-11e9-97e4-a25e09285d99.gif)
**Expected Behavior**: It stays on "Resource file" so I can browse or type in the path to resource file.
**Actual Behavior**: It reverts back to Icon and Manifest
**User Impact**: Frustrating UI.

Issue.Title: Race condition in project editing with undo
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**:
16.2.0-pre.2.0+29006.145. Also occurs in 16.1.3.
**Summary**:
Changes to editor buffer made immediately after save are undone asynchronously after a second or so.
**Steps to Reproduce**:
```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"> <PropertyGroup> <OutputType>Exe</OutputType> <TargetFrameworks>netstandard1.3;netcoreapp2.1</TargetFrameworks> </PropertyGroup> </Project> ```
To trigger the behaviour do the following steps quickly:
1. Delete one TFM (leaving say `netcoreapp2.1`) 1. Save 1. Undo (leaving `netstandard1.3;netcoreapp2.1`)
The undone change is reverted back to `netstandard1.3;netcoreapp2.1` after a second or so. It's as though the save operation is replacing the document content some while later.
**Expected Behavior**:
Editor does not make unexpected changes to file.
**Actual Behavior**:
Editor changes the file.
**User Impact**:
Unclear how far reaching this is. Potential for data loss here.

Issue.Title: Task List does not populate for the Common Project System SLN Guid
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**: 16.1.1
**Summary**: Task List does not populate for the `Common Project System` SLN Guid. [Developer Community Link](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/512025/task-list-does-not-populate-until-file-is-opened.html)
**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. Create a new .Net Core Template project, such as Asp.Net Core project, with the C# language.
2. Add a `// TODO` comment to a couple of files, such as Startup.cs, and Program.cs.
3. Observe that the Task List window is populating as you type them.
4. Close and reopen VS. You'll notice VS auto populates the Task List window still. This is correct behavior.
5. Open the SLN file in a text editor, observe that your project type guid is [Legacy Project Type](https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/blob/f0242ba7034956c27d0a0dedba3b61c30206ab0b/src/Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Managed.VS/ProjectSystem/ProjectType.cs#L47) `FAE04EC0-301F-11D3-BF4B-00C04F79EFBC`.
6. In VS, right click -> Add -> Solution Folder, call it whatever you like, such as `Solution Items`
7. Close and reopen VS. You'll notice VS does **not** auto populate the Task List window anymore. This is wrong.
8. Open a file containing a `// TODO` comment. Task List will populate with **just that comment**, but not any other comments in any other file.
9. Leave that file open, make sure VS is set to restore open documents from previous session, and relaunch VS. You'll notice VS auto populates the Task List window now. It's seemingly only populating Task List because a file containing a `// TODO` comment was open at launch. This is the only workaround I know of.
10. Open the SLN file in a text editor, observe that your project type guid was changed to [Common Project System](https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/blob/f0242ba7034956c27d0a0dedba3b61c30206ab0b/src/Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Managed.VS/ProjectSystem/ProjectType.cs#L37) `9A19103F-16F7-4668-BE54-9A1E7A4F7556`.
11. Change the Guid from `9A19103F-16F7-4668-BE54-9A1E7A4F7556` to `FAE04EC0-301F-11D3-BF4B-00C04F79EFBC`. Reopen VS and regardless as to whether or not a file containing a `// TODO` comment is opened at launch, the Task List window will auto populate as expected.
**Expected Behavior**: Task List window auto populates when the SLN file has the `Common Project System` Guid instead of the `Legacy Project Type` Guid in it, regardless of if I have files with comments in them open at launch or not.
**Actual Behavior**: When no files are set to open at VS launch, Task List is not populated, the Task List window will see items as you open files with the comments in them, but never shows all of them. When there is a file containing a comment in it opens at VS launch, then the Task List window works as expected.
**User Impact**: Task List window helps users find what work they have temporarily set aside. That work may be forgotten if the Task List window doesn't populate, and poor or incomplete code may potentially never be addressed.
**Appendix** SLN file before adding Solution Items. ``` Microsoft Visual Studio Solution File, Format Version 12.00 # Visual Studio Version 16 VisualStudioVersion = 16.0.28922.388 MinimumVisualStudioVersion = 10.0.40219.1 Project("{FAE04EC0-301F-11D3-BF4B-00C04F79EFBC}") = "WebApplication2", "WebApplication2\WebApplication2.csproj", "{F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}" EndProject Global GlobalSection(SolutionConfigurationPlatforms) = preSolution Debug|Any CPU = Debug|Any CPU Release|Any CPU = Release|Any CPU EndGlobalSection GlobalSection(ProjectConfigurationPlatforms) = postSolution {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Debug|Any CPU.ActiveCfg = Debug|Any CPU {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Debug|Any CPU.Build.0 = Debug|Any CPU {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Release|Any CPU.ActiveCfg = Release|Any CPU {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Release|Any CPU.Build.0 = Release|Any CPU EndGlobalSection GlobalSection(SolutionProperties) = preSolution HideSolutionNode = FALSE EndGlobalSection GlobalSection(ExtensibilityGlobals) = postSolution SolutionGuid = {AA0FCE5B-CB21-4C43-8186-1DC7332943CB} EndGlobalSection EndGlobal ```
SLN file after adding Solution Items. ``` Microsoft Visual Studio Solution File, Format Version 12.00 # Visual Studio Version 16 VisualStudioVersion = 16.0.28922.388 MinimumVisualStudioVersion = 10.0.40219.1 Project("{9A19103F-16F7-4668-BE54-9A1E7A4F7556}") = "WebApplication2", "WebApplication2\WebApplication2.csproj", "{F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}" EndProject Project("{2150E333-8FDC-42A3-9474-1A3956D46DE8}") = "Solution Items", "Solution Items", "{8EBC4356-9D75-4D31-A6AB-A8202863EE67}" EndProject Global GlobalSection(SolutionConfigurationPlatforms) = preSolution Debug|Any CPU = Debug|Any CPU Release|Any CPU = Release|Any CPU EndGlobalSection GlobalSection(ProjectConfigurationPlatforms) = postSolution {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Debug|Any CPU.ActiveCfg = Debug|Any CPU {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Debug|Any CPU.Build.0 = Debug|Any CPU {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Release|Any CPU.ActiveCfg = Release|Any CPU {F579B70A-02A1-4100-8706-5592EB3B1624}.Release|Any CPU.Build.0 = Release|Any CPU EndGlobalSection GlobalSection(SolutionProperties) = preSolution HideSolutionNode = FALSE EndGlobalSection GlobalSection(ExtensibilityGlobals) = postSolution SolutionGuid = {AA0FCE5B-CB21-4C43-8186-1DC7332943CB} EndGlobalSection EndGlobal ```

Issue.Title: Detect CPS using Sdk attribute or TargetFramework or TargetFrameworks
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**: 16.0
**Summary:** Currently Visual Studio recognizes CPS projects using either the `TargetFramework` or `TargetFrameworks` MSBuild properties, but they must be defined in the main project file.
Defining the target framework in a central place (e.g. `Directory.Build.props`) makes it easier to upgrade to a new version in large solutions.
My suggestion is to use the `Sdk` attribute (of the `Project` element) as an additional way to detect CPS. I believe it will cover most cases.
See also #3192
**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. Create a directory with a `Directory.Build.props` with `<TargetFramework>netcoreapp2.2</TargetFramework>`. 2. In the same directory, create a new .NET Core library in Visual Studio. 3. Edit the .csproj and remove the `TargetFramework` property.
**Expected Behavior**: VS opens the project and the target framework set to netcore2.2.
**Actual Behavior**: VS requests to reload the solution, and then asks to convert the project. If you decline, the project won't load. If you agree, the project file will be modified to something completely invalid and won't load.

Issue.Title: Classdiagramms in .net standard projects creates .vb files instead of .cs files
Issue.Description:
If I create a .net standard project I can't create a c# class digramm instead I get a vb class diagramm. If I create a class diagramm for Windows Forms App everything works fine.
Steps I did:
1. Disabled all third -party extensions 2. Restarted Visual Studio 3. Created a new C# .Net Standard Project 4. Added a Class Diagramm file (Visual C# Items -> General -> Class Diagramm) 5. Added a class via drag & drop from the toolbox -> "New Class" dialog pops up where I can change the name -> The content of Create new file is "Class1.vb" 6. Changed the extension to .cs and pressed ok -> Got the error message "Visual studio class diagram file name extension is invalid a valid extension is .vb"
I use Visual Studio Community 2017 V.: 15.7.6 I Created a normal C# class library project as workaround.

Issue.Title: Project system guid when downgrading to legacy project
Issue.Description:
**Visual Studio Version**: 15.9.6
**Summary:** I had a project `A` which was created as a new style csproj, but eventually downgraded to legacy style csproj. After downgrading `A`, a solution which referenced `A` using the `9A19103F-16F7-4668-BE54-9A1E7A4F7556` guid could no longer build `A`.
`A` is and it's files are visible in the solution explorer, but I noticed two oddities: * `A` does not show up in the configuration manager * When right clickick on `A` in solution explorer, built, rebuild and clean buttons are not available.
**Steps to Reproduce**:
1. Create a new solution with a new style project. 2. Ensure the project is referenced using `9A19103F-16F7-4668-BE54-9A1E7A4F7556` in the sln file 3. Close VS 4. Replace the content of `A.csproj` with its equivalent legacy style project. 5. Open VS
**Expected Behavior**: Either: * load `A` as legacy project, or * give a error/warning that I'm trying to load a legacy project as a new style project.
**Actual Behavior**: `A` is (partly?) loaded, but cannot be built
**User Impact**: I'm not sure what to write here?

Issue.Title: project.assets.json is a pita
Issue.Description:
Version used: VS2019 Preview1 and basically all versions of 2017.
After changing the `TargetFramework` of an SDK style Project in VS without unloading from `net472` to `netcoreapp2.2`, i've noticed that the `Dependencies` node got a yellow triangle and doing a rebuild yielded ``` Resource file "[...]\obj\project.assets.json" has no target for "netcoreapp2.2". Ensure that the restore is running and that the item "netcoreapp2.2" is included in the TargetFrameworks element for the project. ``` No amount of clicking rebuild, build or clean in VS helps to solve this.
So then i've opened the project folder and removed the `obj` directory (why doesn't clean do this?), and the next rebuild yielded ``` Assets file '[…]\obj\project.assets.json' not found. Run a NuGet package restore to generate this file. ``` again, nothing i can do in VS fixes it. So i drop back to cmd to run `dotnet restore` and voila, it works.
Interestingly enough, from that moment on, changing `TargetFramework` back and forth worked flawlessly, with `Restoring…` flashing in VS statusbar.
Similiar i sometimes open Projects or have Projects that somehow become corrupted and then everything is an error of the `Predefined type 'System.Object' is not defined or imported` sorts. This usually requires closing VS and nuking every temporary VS artifact in the solution.
Another case where you have to manually help is (because it assumed the file that was there at some point in time would still be there) ``` Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets(129,5): error MSB4018: The "GenerateDepsFile" task failed unexpectedly. Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets(129,5): error MSB4018: System.IO.FileNotFoundException: %USERPROFILE%\.nuget\packages\library\version\lib\net40\Library.dll Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets(129,5): error MSB4018: error MSB4018: at System.Linq.Enumerable.<ConcatIterator>d__59`1.MoveNext() Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets(129,5): error MSB4018: at System.Linq.Enumerable.<ConcatIterator>d__59`1.MoveNext() The first was were it was trying to use `newtonsoft.json\7.0.1\lib\net45\Newtonsoft.Json.dll` but only `newtonsoft.json\12.0.1\lib\net45\Newtonsoft.Json.dll` was actually restored. The second encounter was were i was analyzing a obfuscated nuget dependency so i had a deobfuscator run and then i got two dlls in the directory, `Library.dll` and `Library-cleaned.dll`, i've taken a look at the cleaned version in dnSpy and then removed it later again. Now VS complained with above error that `Library-cleaned.dll` was missing. To be fair, it works most of the time but when it runs into cache invalidation problems, then it needs manual Intervention to fix it.

Issue.Title: Up-to-date checks fail after a few time when using conditional globbing
Issue.Description:
Using [this solution](https://github.com/nventive/Uno/blob/1-42/src/Uno.UI.sln), when modifying any cross targeted file in the Uno.UI project (e.g. [this file](https://github.com/nventive/Uno/blob/1-42/src/Uno.UI/UI/Xaml/Controls/NavigationView/NavigationView.cs)), building the project works a few times (2 or 3) then any modification says that nothing has changed, and everything is up to date, even if a file has been modified.
This solution cross targets using msbuild extras, using `xamarinmac20;MonoAndroid80;xamarinios10;net46;netstandard2.0`.
One possible workaround is to add the following:
```xml <ItemGroup> <UpToDateCheckInput Include="**\*.cs" Exclude="bin\**\*.cs;obj\**\*.cs;" /> </ItemGroup> ```
So that VS picks up the changes. This used to happen regularly before VS15.9, now happens all the time.

Issue.Title: Editing a csproj file through the integrated diffing tool is not possible
Issue.Description:
While we now can edit the real csproj for sdk-styled projects, when diffing the csproj files before a commit, the editor still considers the files as readonly. _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/238045/editing-a-csproj-file-through-the-integrated-diffi.html VSTS ticketId: 604467_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Fannie Wang [MSFT] on 24/04/2018, 01:03 PM (209 days ago):

Thank you for your feedback! What's the real csproj for sdk-styled project? For us to investigate this further, could you please provide your exact repro steps? We look forward to hearing from you!

Jérôme Laban on 24/04/2018, 10:25 PM (208 days ago):

Thanks Fannie,

Microsoft is definitely in need for a good name for this type of project file format to avoid confusion :)

Here's how to repro:

  • Create a .NET Standard 2.0 library project
  • Check the create a git repository
  • Commit the current changes
  • Add any nuget package to the project
  • Go the git changes, diff the modified csproj file
  • Try modifying the csproj file on the right pane of the diffing window, notice it is read-only and should not be.

Thank you!

David Kean [MSFT] on 25/04/2018, 08:40 AM (208 days ago):

Reopening this.

I have a shared project between an ASP.NET Core and WPF projects. When I open the shared file and change context, as soon as I set back the focus on the text editor, the context jumps back to the previous project-context.
I encounter the same issue when trying to change project-context using the keyboard (Ctrl+F12) as well.

Posted [here](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/163658/unable-to-change-file-context-in-shared-file-it-im.html) as well.

Issue.Title: Compile TempPE output
Issue.Description:
This is a tracking item for the work to wire up the TempPE compiler in order to bring up WinForms
- [ ] Compile TempPE as part of file generator for resx files - [ ] Compile TempPE via BuildManager for design time builds (#4163)

Issue.Title: "Target framework" dropdown doesn't list full framework options
Issue.Description:
SDK-style projects support targeting .NET Framework TargetFrameworks like `net46` and `net472`, but that's not obvious from the dropdown in project properties:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3347530/46047520-05aef600-c0eb-11e8-9a3a-41fa4057ac26.png)
This caused at least one user to rewrite all of their projects after being told that they needed to target full framework rather than .NET Core, when all that was required was
```diff - <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework> + <TargetFramework>net46</TargetFramework> ```

Issue.Title: Checking "XML Documentation File" creates DocumentationFile element with fully qualified path rather than relative
Issue.Description:
In a netstandard class library or dotnet core app, clicking the "XML documentation file" checkbox on the build tab of the project properties now adds the `DocumentationFile` element on the csproj with a _fully qualified path_ to the XML document to be created on build.
Previously this path was previously relative and remains so for non-sdk project files. This causes issues for build servers where the path of drive specified in the fully qualified path does not exist. It can also put developers usernames into DocumentationFile paths depending on where they have checked code out to on their local system.

Issue.Title: Global.json pinning to not installed version causes load failures and issues in VS
Issue.Description: Not sure where to best put this issue. # Steps to reproduce: 1. Have a .NET Core project + solution (web project in my case) with a global.json pinning the SDK to 2.1.300 2. Have recent VS and only 2.1.400 and 2.1.401 SDKs installed 3. CLI command will then show an error: ``` > dotnet build A compatible SDK version for global.json version: [2.1.300] from [C:\repos\avs-portal\global.json] was not found Did you mean to run dotnet SDK commands? Please install dotnet SDK from: http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=798306&clcid=0x409 ``` 4. Open the solution in VS: # Expected behaviour One of: * The solution loads in VS and the SDK is rolled forward to a more recent installed version * An error similar to the CLI build warning is displayed, including a link to some documentation which aims to explain to users what has gone wrong and how the problem can be fixed. # Actual behaviour when trying to remove the project from the solution:

Issue.Title: Dependencies tree need only load the first level, and lazy creating the subtree, only when user expands it.
Issue.Description:
Dependencies tree is one leading reason that .Net Core project system uses excessive memory. We need create the tree lazily, and remove the majority data from the DTBB output.
(I could not find a task to track this work. Please resolve it as a duplicated, if you have already got one.)

Issue.Title: #if preprocessor not refreshing in editor for new csproj format
Issue.Description:
I am not sure if it was working as expected before but I see that 15.8.0 update of VisualStudio is showing this issue. The `#if DEBUG` preprocessor directives does not auto-update in the editor if the csproj is of newer format starting with `<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">`
Create a new C# library project targetting full framework. Edit your csproj file and replace with following. ```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"> <PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>net471</TargetFramework> <AssemblyVersion>1.0.0.0</AssemblyVersion> <FileVersion>1.0.0.0</FileVersion> </PropertyGroup> <PropertyGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)|$(Platform)'=='Debug|AnyCPU'"> <PlatformTarget>x64</PlatformTarget> <DefineConstants>DEBUG;TRACE</DefineConstants> <OutputPath></OutputPath> </PropertyGroup> <PropertyGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)|$(Platform)'=='Release|AnyCPU'"> <PlatformTarget>x64</PlatformTarget> <OutputPath></OutputPath> </PropertyGroup> <ItemGroup> <Reference Include="System" /> </ItemGroup> </Project> ``` In your CS file try adding below and toggle Debug and Release mode from the dropdown to see if editor refreshes. Expected is that it should update correctly i.e. should be grayed out in Release mode but the observed behavior is that it has no effect and the state is same. ```csharp namespace ClassLibrary1 { public class Class1 { #if DEBUG //do something #endif } ```
EDIT: Cross Reference #2733

Issue.Title: Resource items do not appear in the Solution Explorer in F#
Issue.Description:
It looks like `<Resource>` files do not show in the Solution Explorer (but are passed to the compiler at build time) in F# projects.
```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"> <PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>net461</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup> <ItemGroup> <Resource Include="Foo.xaml" /> <Compile Include="Program.fs" /> </ItemGroup> </Project> ```
Any idea what's causing this? EmbeddedResource items show in the Solution Explorer fine.
This project worked fine with the legacy project system.
Thanks Saul

Issue.Title: Multi targeting project with conditionally included files is not recompiled
Issue.Description:
I have a Xamarin.Forms solution with multiple normal projects for each platform and one multi-targeting project for all platforms.
In the multi .csproj I have ItemGroups like this for each platform:
<ItemGroup Condition=" $(TargetFramework.StartsWith('net4')) "> <PackageReference Include="Xamarin.Forms.Platform.WPF" Version="3.0.0.482510" /> <Compile Include="WPF\**\*.cs" /> </ItemGroup>
If I change something in the WPF folder and press F5 (the WPF project is the startup project), then the multi-targeting project is not automatically recompiled and the app starts at once. I have to manually rebuild the project before starting it with F5.
The same happens if the UWP project is the startup project and I change something in the UWP folder. But I also have an "All" Folder which compiles its files for all platforms. If I change something there, then the project is recompiled automatically.
I tested this with VS versions 15.7.3 up to 15.8.0 preview 4. I already [filed this issue in VS](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/268967/multi-targeting-project-with-conditionally-include.html) a month ago, but unfortunately it needed that long before someone told me that it belongs here.

Issue.Title: Files do not always get copied to the referencing project's output directory
Issue.Description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. In .Net Core 2.0, create a solution with console app project `A` and class library project `L`. 2. Make `A` reference `L`. 3. Add text file `T` to project `L`. 4. Right-click on `T`, select properties, change `Copy to Output Directory` to `Copy if newer`. 5. Build the solution for the 1st time - `T` gets copied to the output folders of both `A` and `L`. 6. Edit `T` and build again - `T` gets updated in the output of `L`, but NOT `A`.
If after editing `T` you `Rebuild` solution, then `T` gets updated in the output folder of both projects, but if you just `Build`, it only gets updated in the output of `L`.

Issue.Title: Need a better experience for failed SDK resolution
Issue.Description:
On project load, if you fail to import an SDK that ultimately would have been what provided common targets, you get a popup like this:
``` --------------------------- Microsoft Visual Studio --------------------------- Project file is incomplete. Expected imports are missing. --------------------------- OK --------------------------- ```
This doesn't give me any sense of what the problem is or how to fix it. The SDK resolver would have logged errors to MSBuild with more details, but they are not shown to the user.
@davkean noted offline: > In flavors, we use to determine up front that the SDK was missing and then do IVsRetargetProject prompting you to install the SDK or point to a page that told you how to get it. > > This is a better experience and works great when you have 100 projects that fail to load.

Issue.Title: Multi-Target Framework project get the reference based on the first in the list.
Issue.Description:
I had a multi-target project set up like this: `<TargetFrameworks>net45;netstandard2.0;portable-net45+win8;</TargetFrameworks>`
and when I add into a solution in the latest VS 2017 (15.7.3) it thinks is a .net framework project and don't show the files under the solution explorer.
Took me a lot of time to find a workaround: Fixed as switching the order in the .csproj file putting the netstandard2.0 in front: `<TargetFrameworks>netstandard2.0;net45;portable-net45+win8;</TargetFrameworks>`

Issue.Title: Reopening #2687: Single File Generators sill broken since 2017
Issue.Description:
Reopening #2687 as the problem still hasn't been fixed. Please actually test solutions before claiming that they are solved. The need to register the single file generators under the new project GUIDs was understood and the code does exactly that.
https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/issues/2687
Custom tools still do not work with Standard projects.
I use a lot of custom tools in my projects. These all run fine in VS2015 and VS2017 with .net framework and/or .net core projects. They do not run at all under Standard projects. The box for custom tool is there, I can fill it in but the custom tool is never run, not even when I invoke it directly. I had thought it was some problem with the tools not registering the correct GUID. But just now I discovered that I have the exact same behavior regardless of whether the tool is present on the system at all. Specifically, my tool is registered as Protogen. In a Framework project, declaring the custom tool as Protogen - Works normally. - correct NotProtogen - Throws tool not found error - correct In a standard project
Protogen - Does nothing, no error - wrong
NotProtogen - Does nothing, no error - wrong I can find no mention of custom tools not working. It will be something of a hassle if I have to resort to running batch files to invoke the tools manualy.
The code for the tools I use is at the following URL. One of the tools generates the binding code for single file generators.
https://github.com/hallambaker/PHB-Build-Tools

Issue.Title: Dependencies tree can run into an endless loop when TargetFramework cannot be evaluated
Issue.Description:
The AWS SDK for .NET solution is quite large and when you open the solution in Visual Studio it maxes out the CPU even when we are not doing anything in Visual Studio. The CPU never appears to go down. The project files were all converted to the newer SDK based csproj files. The solution can be found in GitHub at https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-net/tree/master/sdk and open the AWSSDK.Net45.sln solution file. (commit 0b27e0e95e726d47c0b2f43dfa9aeb4cde6fa44b)
There is a single project “generator\ServiceClientGeneratorLib\ServiceClientGeneratorLib.csproj”, which happens to be in the old C# project format, but the solution file was hardcoded to open it with the new .Net Core factory.
I guess that won’t work very well. The problem here is in the dependencies tree (CrossTargetSubscritionHostBase.cs/UpdateProjectContextAsync function). The code computes the TargetFramework, which will be null. I guess the rule won’t exist there. Anyway, the result is it will create a new context on every call, then UpdateProjectContextAndSubscriptionsAsync will clean up old rule subscriptions, and registers a new set. The later one causes the tree to receive a new set of results, and starts the next round of the loop.
Anyway, the dependencies tree code can be a little bit smarter to know nothing has changed.

Issue.Title: Clearer error then "The project configuration Debug|AnyCPU was not found in the project manifest."
Issue.Description:
Due to intermittent issues with new Visual Studio releases, this error comes and goes. Ultimately Visual Studio 2017 will probably become a reliable product, but for now it would help in analyzing and resolving issues when the following change could be made:
Original text: The project configuration Debug|AnyCPU was not found in the project manifest.
New error text: The project configuration Debug|AnyCPU was not found in the project manifest 'FILENAME'.
Workaround is to remove projects from the solution and then start re-adding them.

Issue.Title: "Assets file '...' doesn't have a target for '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0'. Ensure that restore has run and that you have included 'netcoreapp2.0' in the TargetFrameworks for your project." after upgrading to VS 15.6.3
Issue.Description:
Since updating VS 15.6.2 to 15.6.3 I started receiving the following error after modifying a source file and rebuilding the solution:
``` 12>C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.102\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\build\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(167,5): error : Assets file 'C:\W ork\engine\engine\Loop54.Webserver\obj\project.assets.json' doesn't have a target for '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0'. Ensure that restore has run and that you have included 'netcoreapp2.0' in the TargetFrameworks for your project. 12>Done building project "Loop54.Webserver.csproj" -- FAILED. 12>C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.102\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\build\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(167,5): error : Assets file 'C:\W ork\engine\engine\FSharpModules\obj\project.assets.json' doesn't have a target for '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0'. Ensure that restore has run and that you have included 'netcoreapp2.0' in the TargetFrameworks for your project. 12>Done building project "FSharpModules.fsproj" -- FAILED. ```
That is, the solution initially builds successfully, but if I a change a C# source file and try to build it again the error occurs (every time). If I clean the solution it then builds successfully again.
It doesn't complain about the project I modified, but about 2 of its (indirect dependencies). I also tried modifying other projects and got the same error about some other projects that those depend on, e.g.
``` 7>------ Build started: Project: CSharpSpellmasters, Configuration: Debug Any CPU ------ 7>C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.102\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\build\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(167,5): error : Assets file 'C:\W ork\engine\engine\Loop54.Engine.Core\obj\project.assets.json' doesn't have a target for '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0'. Ensure that restore has run and that you have included 'netcoreapp2.0' in the TargetFrameworks for your project. 7>Done building project "Loop54.Engine.Core.csproj" -- FAILED. ```
I've verified that project.assets.json does have a target for '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0' and also its contents are the same as after a clean (when the build succeeds). I don't have a duplicate ProjectReference as far as I can see or anything else weird. I tried going back to an earlier revision of the code and it still happened there.
The only recent change was upgrading to 15.6.3. I re-installed VS 15.5.7 (which was a huge waste of time!) based on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/productinfo/installing-an-earlier-release-of-vs2017 and the problem disappeared.
Is there a way I can upgrade to 15.6.2, at least? (15.5.7 has another problem I ran into, that was fixed in 15.6.) Can I install an "experimental" version of VS in parallel with my main (stable) one? This waste of time due to what is probably a simple bug is an AWFUL user experience. With almost any other software I'd be able to simply go back to the old version in a few minutes.

Hi Kevin,

From a clean (-fdx) repo, first build compiles all projects, runs a Xamarin.iOS app for instance.

Issue.Title: Adding new *.cs file while having the property EnableDefaultCompileItems on false
Issue.Description:
@edsonaf commented on [Fri Feb 23 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1280)
# Creating new *.cs file while having the property EnableDefaultCompileItems on false does not automatically add this file in the project file
# General
- This is on Visual Studio 2017 Version 15.5.57 - Using the new SDK project format style - Has `<EnableDefaultCompileItems>false</EnableDefaultCompileItems>` - Has external files included using the `<Compile Include="" />` way - Project was ported from the old .net framework project style to the new style as this project is now a netstandard2.0 project.
I can actually fix this issue very easily by just removing the <EnableDefaultCompileItems>false</EnableDefaultCompileItems> and removing the two files that are already included with the `<Compile Include="" />`
However some solutions that we have, have cs files that are compiled with a Prebuild target. To use them while building, they needed to be explicitly added in the project file and therefor the EnableDefaultCompileItems property was also used.

But it only work until I closed the editor and never more. It didn't show the associations neither.
Is there any plan to support this?

Issue.Title: Support file nesting implemented in for dotnet core web projects
Issue.Description:
See this request here: https://github.com/aspnet/websdk/issues/248
Nesting went live in 15.6 Preview 3 and there were requests for other dotnet core projects to support that.
To support nesting, project needs to have following capabilities:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1592091/36112364-441ecdb6-0fde-11e8-99df-acb079bbc646.png)
To add default nesting behavior for your project type, a provider needs to be implemented.
Contact me for details when ready.

Issue.Title: Adding COM reference in csproj breaks other references and intellisense
Issue.Description:
Hi,
I have found an issue where by if I add a reference to a COM library in a ASP.NET Core WebAPI project targeting the .NET framework it has the side effect of breaking Intellisense and raising false errors in the Error list window. Mainly that it can't find namespaces and symbols referenced in the non-COM project references. Everything still compiles and works, but it just makes code refactoring and following references incredibly difficult.
I have attached an example project where if you remove the commenting around lines 22 - 31 of ComBreakingExample.csproj you should hopefully see the issue.
Any help is much appreciated. Many thanks, James
[ComBreakingExample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/files/1710464/ComBreakingExample.zip)

Issue.Title: VS 15.5.4 does not add explicitly code file created with new item command when EnableDefaultCompileItems is set to false
Issue.Description: One of the configuration options for new format project files allows to switch off default globbing patterns used for including compile items into csproj. When `EnableDefaultCompileItems` is set to false it is impossible to add new code file to project when using `Add New Item` command. Code file is created in the project directory be it Interface or Class but it is not added explicitly as `<Compile Include"Class.cs"/>` despite `EnableDefaultCompileItems` being set to false. As a result file is not compiled with project.

Issue.Title: $(OutDir) unexpected behavior or $(OutDir) is undefined
Issue.Description:
I have C# 'Microsoft.NET.Sdk' project in D:\Projects\Asm Project is configured for multibuild for net40;net45;net47;netstandard2.0 It have `<DocumentationFile>$(OutDir)\Asm.xml</DocumentationFile>` parameter
Documentation files **are generating** in output dirs, **but also** in D:\Asm.xml
When I use: ``` <PropertyGroup Condition="'$(OutDir)'!=''"> <DocumentationFile>$(OutDir)\Asm.xml</DocumentationFile> </PropertyGroup> ``` No documentation files are generated
When project is located in standard location %userprofile%\source\repos\ project cannot be build (because it cannot write to C:\Asm.xml)
Workaround is use `<DocumentationFile>bin\$(Configuration)\$(TargetFramework)\Asm.xml</DocumentationFile>` but it makes sides effects when project is build not from Visual Studio

Issue.Title: Package manager now uses a <Version> child element?
Issue.Description:
I'm not sure if we did something wrong, but after upgrading to the latest version of VS, our packages are included a new (much harder to read) format.
For instance, they used to be formatted like ``` <PackageReference Include="Common.Logging" Version="3.4.1" /> ``` But when they're touched by the package manager, they are now of the format ``` <PackageReference Include="Common.Logging"> <Version>3.4.1</Version> </PackageReference> ``` Are we doing something weird? Is this expected? I can't find any documentation on it being changed (other than some old references that don't look relevant)

Issue.Title: [Dependencies] Regression when adding newly created project reference, it is always yellow even though has hierarchy
Issue.Description:
VS Dev15.5 Preview 2 d15rel 27016.0
Repro steps (we have automated integration test and i tried them manually too):
1. Create a new core 2.0 Web app wait for restore, save solution 2. Creat a new ClassLibrary core 2.0, wait for restore 3. Add project reference web->classlib via Add Reference dialog, wait for restore:
Actual result:
Project dependency appears in the web but is yellow, However it does have hierarchy under it.
Expected dependency to be normal since targets frameworks are the same for web and classlib.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1592091/31685702-ccd0b064-b338-11e7-8ac1-90e69d089059.png)

Issue.Title: VB Property Pages Imported Namespaces Checkboxes Break After First Selection
Issue.Description:
From [VSFeedback](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/123202/references-page-project-designer-visual-basic-impo.html) | [503013](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/503013)
**Repro Steps** In a Desktop VB Project, go to Properties | References | Imported Namespaces. Uncheck the namespace "Microsoft.VisualBasic" Check the namespace "Microsoft.VisualBasic" Uncheck the namespace "Microsoft.VisualBasic"
**Expected** Namespace is unchecked
**Actual** A different namespace is unchecked. Subsequent selections do not check or uncheck the expected boxes and the whole experience is broken, at least from a UI perspective.
**Workaround** Edit `Import` itemgroup in the vbproj file

Issue.Title: F5 Working directory for SDK-based Console Apps is different from Desktop Apps
Issue.Description:
The following program emits different outputs for Desktop Apps and Sdk-based apps with default settings:
```csharp class Program { static void Main(string[] args) { Console.WriteLine(System.IO.Directory.GetCurrentDirectory()); } } ```
From [VSFeedback](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/119648/the-working-directory-for-projects-using-the-new-c.html) | [500011](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/500011)
> **The working directory for projects using the new csproj format is the project directory rather than bin\\$(configuration)\\$(targetFramework)** > > This applies to both 15.3 and 15.4 preview. > > When you use the new csproj format, the working directory is the root of the csproj file rather than the output directory where the executing binary lives. > > If you execute the exe directly from file explorer, the working directory is the directory containing the exe. > > This is not intuitive for accessing files which are copied to the output directory for access when the program is executing. > > A workaround for this is to add the following code before referencing any files that you expect to be in the output directory: > var exePath = new Uri(Assembly.GetEntryAssembly().CodeBase).LocalPath; > var directory = Path.GetDirectoryName(exePath); > Directory.SetCurrentDirectory(directory); >
Workaround is to set the working directory from Project Properties | Debug | Working Directory

Issue.Title: Adding existing project requires VS to upgrade the project
Issue.Description:
When I add an existing .net project (one that is compliant with the new csproj format for VS2017), VS prompts me to "upgrade" the project. From what I can tell -- there is nothing causing the upgrade as I have a number of other projects that are in the same format that I added fine with earlier builds of VS2017.
This is something that I have noticed in the latest version of VS2017. 15.3.3.
Once the project upgrades and is added to the solution, I have noticed a number of things happen: 1) VS adds the project to the solution with this guid: FAE04EC0-301F-11D3-BF4B-00C04F79EFBC Where other projects are added with this guid: 9A19103F-16F7-4668-BE54-9A1E7A4F7556
2) It adds an "Any CPU" profile to the solution and all existing projects -- where the project I add has a Platforms tag of x64. All projects prior also only had an x64 target.
3) When loaded in VS, the project can not be "edited" normally like the other projects. I have to unload the project before editing.
4) The project itself is converted from: \<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"/\> to \<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" ToolsVersion="15.0"/\>
It also adds a few properties, such as FileUpgradeFlags,UpgradeBackupLocation and OldToolsVersion.
Is this experience expected?
To resolve this, I change the guid in the solution file to the "9A19103..." and revert the project header back to the Microsoft.NET.Sdk (minus the ToolsVersion). Things then work as expected and I can edit the project file without unloading.

Issue.Title: Define LaunchSettings.json outside of project
Issue.Description:
I have a couple of that have a bit more complicated launchsettings.json. And I don't want to maintain this file per project. Each project already has a common imported .targets file. And in this target I have include my custom launchsettings.json file. It now loads the file correctly but it is placed in the root project directory and my project won't launch.
I don't know how visual studio recognizes the launchsettings.json file but i expect it has to be places in properties directory for it to work correctly.
So my question is can you include an external file into a specific directory in the project?

Issue.Title: dotnet cli created projects don't work in VS2017 15.3.3.
Issue.Description:
_From @codefactorydevelopment on September 9, 2017 13:58_
## Steps to reproduce
Create 2 projects:
1. `dotnet new webapi` (name: webapiProject) 2. `dotnet new xunit` (name: testProject)
After that, on `testProject` project: `dotnet add reference webapiProject`
Now, when opening testProject.csproj in `VS2017 15.3.3.`
## Expected behavior Expected to see `testProject` loaded with resolved dependency to `webapiProject`
## Actual behavior
When opening testProj.csproj in VS2017 15.3.3. the following Nuget **NU1105** error occurs:
*Severity Code Description Project File Line Suppression State Error NU1105 Unable to find project information for 'webapiProject'. The project file may be invalid or missing targets required for restore.*
Dependencies & build work as expected when done from `dotnet cli`.
## Environment data `dotnet --info` output:
.NET Command Line Tools (2.0.0)
Product Information: Version: 2.0.0 Commit SHA-1 hash: cdcd1928c9
Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.14393 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.0.0\
Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host
Version : 2.0.0 Build : e8b8861ac7faf042c87a5c2f9f2d04c98b69f28d
_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7623_

Issue.Title: Tooling keeps inserting ItemGroup.Compile items into csproj after update to Windows 10 Redstone 3 Preview
Issue.Description:
Hello,
I updated my computer to the latest Windows 10 Redstone 3 Insider Preview a few days ago, and ever since that update I have been having tooling issues in Visual Studio with .NET Core SDK. Whenever I try to rename a file in Visual Studio, instead of executing a move command, it is creating a copy of the old file but with the new name. It is also adding an item group into my csproj file.
**Steps to reproduce:** 1) Create a new .NET Standard 2.0 class library using Visual Studio 2) Open `Class1.cs` and save it (this will cause the file icon to change to not found): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5934505/30174513-36b984e0-93b0-11e7-9618-7d34f3a91da8.png)
3) Rename `Class1.cs` to `Class2.cs`
Notice that on disk the following files now exist: ``` Class1.cs Class2.cs ClassLibraryX.csproj ```
Also notice that your csproj now looks like this (for some reason, it created an item group and added the renamed file): ```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
<PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup>
<ItemGroup> <Compile Include="Class2.cs" /> </ItemGroup> </Project> ```
And when you compile, you will get the following error: ``` Severity Code Description Project File Line Suppression State Error Duplicate 'Compile' items were included. The .NET SDK includes 'Compile' items from your project directory by default. You can either remove these items from your project file, or set the 'EnableDefaultCompileItems' property to 'false' if you want to explicitly include them in your project file. For more information, see https://aka.ms/sdkimplicititems. The duplicate items were: 'Class2.cs' ClassLibraryX C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.0.0\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\build\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.DefaultItems.targets 263
```
When I debug the project-system project, I get the following exception: ``` CPS Error: 0 : Exception while reading file attributes for "C:\Users\chaws\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ClassLibrary6\ClassLibrary6\Class1.cs~RF3ac9ae.TMP". System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not find file 'C:\Users\chaws\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ClassLibrary6\ClassLibrary6\Class1.cs~RF3ac9ae.TMP'. File name: 'C:\Users\chaws\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ClassLibrary6\ClassLibrary6\Class1.cs~RF3ac9ae.TMP' at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath) at System.IO.File.GetAttributes(String path) at Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Designers.CoreDirectoryTreeProvider.IsHiddenFile(String fullPath) CPS Error: 0 : Exception while reading file attributes for "C:\Users\chaws\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ClassLibrary6\ClassLibrary6\Class1.cs~RF3ac9ae.TMP". System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not find file 'C:\Users\chaws\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ClassLibrary6\ClassLibrary6\Class1.cs~RF3ac9ae.TMP'. File name: 'C:\Users\chaws\Documents\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\ClassLibrary6\ClassLibrary6\Class1.cs~RF3ac9ae.TMP' at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath) at System.IO.File.GetAttributes(String path) at Microsoft.VisualStudio.ProjectSystem.Designers.CoreDirectoryTreeProvider.IsHiddenFile(String fullPath) ```
Windows 10 Version: 10.0.16278.1000 (rs3_release.170825-1441)
Visual Studio Version: Enterprise 2017 v15.4.0 Preview 1.0

Issue.Title: No IntelliSense for ProjectReference with the same embedded COMReference
Issue.Description:
I have two projects with the same COMReference: ```xml <COMReference Include="MSHTML"> <Guid>{3050F1C5-98B5-11CF-BB82-00AA00BDCE0B}</Guid> <VersionMajor>4</VersionMajor> <VersionMinor>0</VersionMinor> <Lcid>0</Lcid> <WrapperTool>tlbimp</WrapperTool> <Isolated>False</Isolated> <EmbedInteropTypes>True</EmbedInteropTypes> </COMReference> ``` The first project is referenced by the second one via a ProjectReference. Building the projects does work but in the second project I don't get IntelliSense for the types of the first one.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4009570/29724028-3e34c4c0-89c7-11e7-96b5-d49940bd810b.png)
If I reference the output dll from the first project then IntelliSense works.
Here is a demo solution: https://github.com/campersau/dotnetcore-project-comreference
Also posted on Visual Studio Feedback: https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/101725/projectreference-to-a-net-core-project-with-comref.html

Issue.Title: Legacy project system does not reload targets
Issue.Description:
_From @Portikus on April 24, 2017 9:9_
**Version Used**: VisualStudio 2017 / 15.1 (26403.7) Release
**Steps to Reproduce**: In the attached repo solution : [SuppressRoslynWarningsBug.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/files/950915/SuppressRoslynWarningsBug.zip) I configured a project to use a shared.props file . In this file there is a variable specified which contains all warnings I want to suppress (in this case IDE0019). Furthermore there is a `Class1` which code causes a IDE0019 warning:
````csharp var str = obj as string; if (str != null) { } ```` So the warning will be suppressed but: 1. Open the shared.props file 2. Remove the IDE0019 3. Close and reload the solution
**Expected Behavior**: Now I expected that the warning wont be supressed anymore but it is still suppressed.
This is not the only Issue I get with a shared property file in combination with the suppression of warnings. In my Solution (45 netstandard and UWP projects) I added recently 3.Party analyser and I wanted to supress some of their warnings. So I added these warnings to my shared.props file. But some of these warnings are not suppressed. I tried to reproduce this in a small environment but then I got the issue descriped above. Maybe there is a general problem with suppression of warnings using a shared.props file?
I hope you can help me.
_Copied from original issue: dotnet/roslyn#18942_

Issue.Title: 'Add Migrations' after Migrating to 2.0
Issue.Description:
I've posted this issue on the [EntityFrameworkCore](https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore) repo. For details see https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore/issues/9506
The issue is that when adding migrations with the dotnet core 2.0 tooling, a Visual Studio UI bug occurs in the Solution Explorer.

Issue.Title: CS8032: analyzer cannot be created after changing PackageReference
Issue.Description:
When changing the version of a package reference that includes an analyzer, the project system will generate a bunch of CS8032 warnings. The warning says that the analyzer from the old version of the PackageReference cannot be created, even though this has been uninstalled.
**Repro** 1. Create a new test project that references xunit 2.3.0-beta2: https://www.nuget.org/packages/xunit/2.3.0-beta2-build3683. This has xunit.analyzers 0.1.0 2. Open in VS 3. Keeping VS open, edit the csproj file and change xunit to 2.3.0-beta4: https://www.nuget.org/packages/xunit/2.3.0-beta4-build3742. This has xunit.analyzers 0.6.0
**Result** The Error List window displays hundreds of CS8032 warnings, all with the same message. They don't go away, even if you unload/reload the project.
``` Warning CS8032: An instance of analyzer Xunit.Analyzers.MemberDataShouldReferenceValidMember cannot be created from C:\Users\namc\.nuget\packages\xunit.analyzers\0.6.1\analyzers\dotnet\cs\xunit.analyzers.dll: Could not load type 'Xunit.Analyzers.MemberDataShouldReferenceValidMember' from assembly 'xunit.analyzers, Version=0.1.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'.. FS.Composite.Tests(net461) 1 Active ```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2696087/29387731-4666757c-8296-11e7-877c-ca3ac4b46570.png)
cref https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/1307

etcoreapp2.0\xunit.runner.visualstudio.dotnetcore.testadapter.dll' does not exist. (XUnitTestProject1) 1>FastUpToDate: Project is not up to date. (XUnitTestProject1) ```
This error indicates that it's because a dll copied by xunit's targets is not present, but that file does exist in the filesystem.
``` banana@FORSYTH C:\codeepro-netcore-up2date-xunit\XUnitTestProject1 > dir bin\Debug
etcoreapp2.0\xunit.runner.visualstudio.dotnetcore.testadapter.dll Volume in drive C has no label. Volume Serial Number is AA75-F51B
Directory of C:\codeepro-netcore-up2date-xunit\XUnitTestProject1 in\Debug
etcoreapp2.0
19/02/2017 03:24 PM 53,760 xunit.runner.visualstudio.dotnetcore.testadapter.dll 1 File(s) 53,760 bytes 0 Dir(s) 57,012,834,304 bytes free ```
I've tried updating both packages to the latest xunit 2.3.0-beta4-build3742, but that makes no difference to the result (a different dll is said to not exist, just as erroneously).

Issue.Title: Adding resource with culture sets unnecessary ResXFileCodeGenerator metadata, pollutes error list
Issue.Description:
## Setup * VS Version:15.3.0 Preview 7.0 [26730.0.d15rel] * .NET Core SDK Version: 2.0.0-preview3-006908
## Repro steps * File -> New Project -> .NET Core -> Console App * Add Item -> ResourcesFile -> Resource1.fr.-CA.resx
## Expected result * As with legacy project system, no ResxFileCodeGenerator metadata is set because the resource file has a specific (non-neutral) culture and therefore no corresponding .Designer.cs. * There are no errors in my error list when I edit the newly created resx file.
## Actual result * ResxFileCodeGenerator is set incorrectly ``` xml <EmbeddedResource Update="Resource1.fr-CA.resx"> <Generator>ResXFileCodeGenerator</Generator> </EmbeddedResource> ``` * There is an error in my error list while editing the resx file
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/75470/28851338-af4ee1d0-76d6-11e7-88be-bc312c4bfd81.png)

Issue.Title: Deduplicate properties in rules for item types
Issue.Description:
Currently there is a large amount of duplication of properties in the rules for various item types. For example, the **Build Action** property appears in every single item type rule. These properties should be de-duplicated through inheritance/extensions after the underlying project system is updated to support such a feature.
The mechanism for this extensibility should also be documented for external developers. Users working with `ObjectExtenders` in the old project system already implemented extension properties this way. As they migrate to supporting the new project system, the lack of an equivalent feature will be a pain point.

Issue.Title: [Dependencies] When have netcoreapp1.1 referencing netcoreapp2.0 there is error in error list from NuGet. however Dependencies tree does not mark unsupported project with yellow icon
Issue.Description: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1592091/28549111-e8ac03c2-708c-11e7-8df1-52ecb449a227.png)

Issue.Title: Suggestion: Store indentation and code guidelines in project
Issue.Description:
Hi,
There should be an option to store the current VS coding-guidelines into the project, so when saving a file in a project that has custom coding-guidelines applied, the indentations, brace-placing, and other coding guidelines are preserved/adapted as to the project settings. This will make it easier to work with GIT projects with different coding-guidelines (especially indentation, which affects the whole file). A dev will be able to open a project with coding-guidelines different than his own, work on the file with his own indentation, then when saving, the file will be saved under the project's indentation setting.

Issue.Title: AvailableItemName provided by a NuGet package isn't available as Build Action
Issue.Description:
In the legacy project system, AvailableItemName provided by a nuget package targets are shown in the properties window (at least if the project is opened when the package has already been restored):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/169707/26728406/83e0659e-4780-11e7-9ae5-721e7680ad2f.png)
The new project system, however, appears to always show a fixed list that does not include those:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/169707/26728442/a12b2bde-4780-11e7-98d6-b269d246eb9a.png)
It would be ideal if the new project system not only preserved the original behavior, but additionally refreshed the list of available build actions/item names whenever packages are installed/restored to make for a nicer extensibility experience via nugets + targets.
(screenshots taken with a .NETStandard 2.0 class library with 15.3 Preview - 26530.1.d15rel) and a regular .NET46 class library.
Since this is a regression from the legacy project system, I think at least the basic behavior should be fixed (even if the auto-refresh isn't).

Issue.Title: Switching configurations does not update the language service
Issue.Description:
1. Create a new Console app (.NET Core) 2. Edit ConsoleApp1.csproj and replace the contents with:
``` XML <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
<PropertyGroup> <OutputType>Exe</OutputType> <TargetFramework>netcoreapp1.1</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup>
<ItemGroup> <Compile Remove="Program.cs" /> <Compile Include="Program.cs" Condition="'$(Configuration)' == 'Release'" /> </ItemGroup> </Project> ```
3. Save 4. Change Configurations from Debug -> Release 5. Open Program.cs
**Expected:** For the file to be in the project **Actual:** File is in misc project.

Issue.Title: Automatically nest *.Designer files
Issue.Description:
Possibly a dupe of #1272, but filing again for the more general scenario.
Whenever a *.Designer.cs file is added to a project, it should automatically nest under its parent of the same name.
This used to work in xproj, but the functionality never made it into the new project system.
This is important for EF Core since each migrations adds two files (e.g. `MyMigration.cs` and `MyMigration.Designer.cs`) and the list of items under the Migrations folder is twice as long as it is on other project types.
The workaround, of course, is to add the following to your csproj.
```XML <ItemGroup> <Compile Update="MyMigration.Designer.cs"> <DependentUpon>MyMigration.cs</DependentUpon> </Compile> </ItemGroup> ```

Issue.Title: Class generation in nested namespaces swaps namespace order for generated directories
Issue.Description:
Hey, I’ve noticed the following issue with the class code generation in Visual Studio 2017 (15.1 26403.7) using the new .csproj format:
1. Create a .NETStandard library project.
2. Create some class inside the namespace `Service.Internal` (created directories accordingly). It should look like this:
![Project with a simple folder structure `Service.Internal.MyService`](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/132240/25621981/4c247298-2f53-11e7-8f95-1f78c7ebdc4f.png)
3. Reference a non-existent type in the class, and use the quick fix bulb to generate the type:
![Referencing a non-existent type, and generating that type using the quick fix bulb](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/132240/25622034/7f501794-2f53-11e7-95c8-ef5edb2a0853.png)
4. Observe the resulting folder structure:
![Created `Utility` class is in the folder `Internal.Services` instead of `Service.Internal`](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/132240/25622117/b4c4af98-2f53-11e7-90d8-a44990d880af.png)
Obviously, the `Utility` class should have been created next to the `MyService` file in the same folder. The rest of the process works correctly, especially the actual namespace for the `Utility` class is correct.

Issue.Title: Cannot navigate to project from Find Results Window
Issue.Description:
1. Right-click project and choose Edit [project] 2. Edit -> File In Files 3. Change Look in to "Current Document" 4. Find a term in the project file 5. Click Find All
Expected:
Project file is opened for editing.
Actual: ``` --------------------------- Microsoft Visual Studio --------------------------- The document 'C:\sample.csproj' is already open as a project or a solution and cannot be opened in an editor at this time. --------------------------- OK --------------------------- ```

Issue.Title: VS2017 project drop down sometimes doesn't work
Issue.Description:
Sometimes the VS2017 project drop down sometimes doesn't work.
Repo: 1. Open Newtonsoft.Json.Roslyn.sln in VS2017 2. Open a cs file 3. Choose a new project in the project dropdown, e.g. file opens as .NET 2, change the project drop down to .NET 4.5 4. The cs file is not updated to reflect .NET 4.5. Clicking on the text editor area causes the project drop down to change from .NET 4.5 back to .NET 2
Note that sometimes this happens, while other times the project is successfully changed.
Project: https://github.com/JamesNK/Newtonsoft.Json/blob/master/Src/Newtonsoft.Json/Newtonsoft.Json.Roslyn.csproj

Issue.Title: Move capabilities from language-specific to "managed"
Issue.Description:
See: https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/issues/2013
We should move the language-specific capabilities on components, such as: ``` [AppliesTo(ProjectCapability.CSharpOrVisualBasicOrFSharp)] ```
-and-
``` [AppliesTo(ProjectCapability.CSharpOrVisualBasicOrFSharpLanguageService)] ```
To a more general capability, such as:
``` [AppliesTo("Managed + CPS")] ```
Make note that C++/CLI uses "Managed", so we should either combine with "CPS" to avoid that (they don't define it) or come up with a new capability.

Issue.Title: Old and new csproj files don't play nicely together
Issue.Description:
While migrating from the old csproj to the new format I came across this issue. If you have a new csproj in the same folder as the old csproj then an error occurs when building the old csproj using VS2017.
> C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\MSBuild\Microsoft\NuGet\15.0\Microsoft.NuGet.targets(197,5): error : Your project is not referencing the ".NETFramework,Version=v4.5.2" framework. Add a reference to ".NETFramework,Version=v4.5.2" in the "frameworks" section of your project.json, and then re-run NuGet restore.
I've narrowed it down to this target in Microsoft.NuGet.targets that runs if there is a `project.assets.json` file in the `obj` folder.
``` <Target Name="ResolveNuGetPackageAssets" DependsOnTargets="$(ResolveNuGetPackageAssetsDependsOn)" Condition="'$(ResolveNuGetPackages)' == 'true' and exists('$(ProjectLockFile)')"> ```
If I delete the `project.assets.json` file then the old project builds without issue. Building the new csproj creates the assets file, which causes the issue to reappear. Removing this target also allows it to build successfully.
Is there a way to detect if the project being built is using the new csproj format within the targets file to workaround this?
Repro solution is here https://github.com/alexwiese/old-vs-new-repro

Issue.Title: Opening a project when there's an open .cd file fails to load the class designer
Issue.Description:
1) Open or create a new project 2) Add a class designer file to the project 3) Close the solution. Make sure the file in the second step is open so that it automatically opens next time the solution is loaded 4) Reopen the solution
Expected: File loads with no errors Actual: There's an error coming from the designer
Debugging through the class designer code the issue is that it's requesting the code model instance from the DTE project and at that point in time it returns null. This doesn't happens if opening the file after the project is loaded (or even putting a breakpoint right before the code model call and waiting a little) so this is a race condition on code model being ready after the project is opened.
This doesn't repros on the legacy project system or C++ projects

Issue.Title: Create Perf tests
AvailableItemName not working through NuGet
Issue.Description:
### Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a new .NET Standard project in Visual Studio 2017 2. Add the [Antlr4](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Antlr4) NuGet package (version 4.6.1-beta002 or higher) 3. Reload the project (to avoid #113) 4. Create a file **Test.g4** and attempt to set the build action to `Antlr4`
### Actual result:
Antlr4 is not an available build action.
### Expected result:
Build action should have been changed.

Issue.Title: Adding a file to a cross targeted project only adds it to a single context
Issue.Description: I'm working in the ASP.NET repositories which has mostly converted to the new csproj. Libraries usually target net451 and netstandard1.3. Whenever I add a file to one of these projects it only ever seems to exist in a single context (I believe the first one declared in the file). If I add the file on disk it appears in both, if I close and re-open the solution it appears in both.

Issue.Title: If you customize conditional constants, and then switch targets, the "implicit" constants get baked in
Issue.Description:
1. File -> New -> Class Library (.NET Standard) 2. Project Properties -> Build -> Add ";FOO" to conditional symbols 3. Retarget from .NET Standard 1.4 -> .NET Standard 1.6 4. Close Project Properties 5. Reopen Project Properties -> Build 6. Constants are even though I'm targeting 1.6:
``` NETSTANDARD1_4;FOO ```
Really think we need to rethink how this works - CPS has support for this with the properties, you add the constants after the project in targets, and you tell CPS to grab the browse object property before then.

Issue.Title: Project System expects TargetFramework property in the csproj itself, and not in an imported props/targets file.
Issue.Description:
# Description The default project template looks like the following: ```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"> <PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>netcoreapp1.0</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup> </Project> ```
I have a set of shared props/targets that are imported by every project in my repo. In order for these to be imported properly, I first have to get rid of the `Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk"` attribute and manually call the appropriate imports. This leaves me with: ```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <Project> <PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>netcoreapp1.0</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup> <Import Project="$(MSBuildSDKsPath)\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\Sdk\Sdk.props" /> <Import Project="$(MSBuildSDKsPath)\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\Sdk\Sdk.targets" /> </Project> ```
I can then import my shared props/targets files and things continue to work as expected: ```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <Project> <Import Project="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\..\Imports\Common\<RepoName>.Common.props" /> <PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>netcoreapp1.0</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup> <Import Project="$(MSBuildSDKsPath)\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\Sdk\Sdk.props" /> <Import Project="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\..\Imports\Common\<RepoName>.Common.targets" /> <Import Project="$(MSBuildSDKsPath)\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\Sdk\Sdk.targets" /> </Project> ```
I then generally take this a step further and declare another set of props/targets. These import the Common props/targets and declare any specifics to a particular target framework (so I might have a `<RepoName>.Desktop` props/targets and a `<RepoName>.Portable` props/targets for example). These generally define the target framework and additionally import the appropriate framework props/targets: So I would end up with:
**\<RepoName>.Portable.props** ```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <Project> <Import Project="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\Common\<RepoName>.Common.props" /> <PropertyGroup> <TargetFramework>netcoreapp1.0</TargetFramework> </PropertyGroup> <Import Project="$(MSBuildSDKsPath)\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\Sdk\Sdk.props" /> </Project> ```
**\<RepoName>.Portable.targets** ```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <Project> <Import Project="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\Common\<RepoName>.Common.targets" /> <Import Project="$(MSBuildSDKsPath)\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\Sdk\Sdk.targets" /> </Project> ```
**Project.csproj** ```xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <Project> <Import Project="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\..\Imports\Portable\<RepoName>.Portable.props" /> <Import Project="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\..\Imports\Portable\<RepoName>.Portable.targets" /> </Project> ```
# Issue This last step fails and I get a dialog stating the following: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10487869/22397945/60e99cf0-e532-11e6-91f6-cf4cfe0530fb.png)
# Expected Behavior Since the resulting project file is the same overall (just with a level of indirection on certain imports), I would expect the project system to successfully load the project and continue working as normal.

Issue.Title: Changes made to the Debug property page are saved even when I save don't save changes
Issue.Description:
Repro #1:
1. File -> New -> Console App (.NET Core) 2. Right-click on project, choose Properties 3. Click Application, change Assembly name to "Foo" 4. Click Debug, change Arguments to "FooBar" 5. Close Solution and choose No when prompted to Save 6. Reopen project
Expected: Neither changes to be saved Actual: The assembly name change is discard (as expected). the Debug properties change is saved.
Repro #2:
1. File -> New -> Console App (.NET Core) 2. Right-click on project ,and choose Properties 3. Make any change to debug page and switch tabs for launchsettings.json to be created 4. In Explorer, mark launchsettings.json as "read-only" 5. Make any change to debug page 6. File -> Close Solution
Get prompted with:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1103906/22192818/5b3a92dc-e18b-11e6-9bb6-df5b30f8ae95.png)
Click Cancel cancels the closing of the solution, I **cannot** discard my changes.

Issue.Title: Add Windows Form does not nest .designer.cs under .cs
Issue.Description:
I was not able to tell if this issue was already tracked.
Start with this .csproj (15.0.26014.0):
```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" ToolsVersion="15.0"> <PropertyGroup> <OutputType>Exe</OutputType> <TargetFramework>net452</TargetFramework> <RuntimeIdentifier>win</RuntimeIdentifier> </PropertyGroup> <ItemGroup> <Compile Include="**\*.cs" /> <EmbeddedResource Include="**\*.resx" /> </ItemGroup> <ItemGroup> <Reference Include="System.Windows.Forms" /> </ItemGroup> </Project> ```
Select Windows Form in Add New Item and see Form1.cs and Form1.designer.cs nodes are siblings in Solution Explorer, and this is the .csproj:
```xml <Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" ToolsVersion="15.0"> <PropertyGroup> <OutputType>Exe</OutputType> <TargetFramework>net452</TargetFramework> <RuntimeIdentifier>win</RuntimeIdentifier> </PropertyGroup> <ItemGroup> <Compile Include="**\*.cs" /> <EmbeddedResource Include="**\*.resx" /> </ItemGroup> <ItemGroup> <Reference Include="System.Windows.Forms" /> </ItemGroup> <ItemGroup> <Compile Update="Form1.cs"> <SubType>Form</SubType> </Compile> <Compile Update="Form1.Designer.cs"> <SubType>Form</SubType> </Compile> </ItemGroup> </Project> ```

Issue.Title: Allow selection of .NETCore/.NETStandard version during project create.
Issue.Description:
_From @eyalsk on December 1, 2016 0:4_
_Disclaimer: Sorry if this is the wrong place to write it but I've reported this before on uservoice and other places such as msft blogs and nothing was done with it._
This is relevant to all versions of Visual Studio but maybe it can be changed for Visual Studio 15 RTM.
So when we create a new project today in Visual Studio and open the New Project dialog the .NET framework version dropdown appears at the top regardless to the selected template!
Even if I select a C++ project I still see this dropdown, I'm using Visual Studio for many, many years to me it's an annoyance but to new comers it can be totally confusing.
I feel like from a user experience perspective this dropdown needs to be shown only when you select a .NET project template, when you select a .NET Core project I feel it should list all the relevant versions for .NET Core as opposed to all the versions of the full .NET framework that has nothing to do with it.
_Copied from original issue: dotnet/roslyn#15621_

Issue.Title: Project System: Find in Files should search in project files
Issue.Description:
If you do a Find in Files with a loaded project, VS doesn't search in the project file.
A couple of things to make sure:
[Find In Solution](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn-project-system/issues/1292) works [Open from search results](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn-project-system/issues/1291) works.
## Current State:
With this in-progess PR: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_git/VS/pullrequest/124985 (Microsofties-only sorry), the following works:
### What works: If project file is closed:
- [x] **Find in Files**/**Find All** set to **Project** or **Solution**
If project file is open but not active:
- [x] **Find in Files**/**Find All** set to **Project** or **Solution** - [x] **Find** set to **Project** or **Solution**
If project file is open and active:
- [x] **Find** set to **Solution** - [x] **Find in Files**/**Find All** set to **Solution** - [x] **Incremental Find**
### What doesn't work:
If project file is open and active (**cause:** issue 1):
- [ ] **Find** set to **Project** - [ ] **Find in Files**/**Find All** set to **Project** (returns "No files were found to look in")
If project file is closed (**cause:** issue 2):
- [ ] **Find** set to **Project** or **Solution**
If AppDesigner is open (**cause:** issue 3)
- [ ] **Find** set to **Project** or **Solution**
Other: - [ ] [Attempting to open the project file from Results window displays an error](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/603147)
### Issues that need to be solved:
- [ ] 1. If the project file is open and active, Monitor Service thinks Solution is the active hierarchy and not the project. - [ ] 2. FindOrOpenFile (FindUtil.cpp) is blocking opening the project file because RDT is returning RDT_ProjSlnDocument. Even if it does return, it asks ShellOpenDocumentService to OpenDocumentViaProject via LOGVIEWID_TextView. - [ ] 3. If AppDesigner is open, ShellOpenDocumentService wants to activate it with a different logical view IVsMultiViewDocumentView.ActivateLogicalView
